Award.AwardTitle: Topics in number theory, dynamical systems and discrete geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
There have recently been many important interactions between number theory and other fields, including dynamical systems and discrete geometry. The connection of number theory with discrete geometry structures via packings leads to connections with problems in materials science. Problems in number theory involving zeta functions and distribution of primes have parallels with problems in mathematical physics. There are further connections of number theory with physical theories such as conformal field theory through modular forms. Number theory structure appears in some exactly solvable models of phase transitions in physical models. The proposal investigates several possible areas of contact between fields, which may lead to fruitful interactions with researchers in physics and material sciences. The grant will support the training of graduate students in these areas.



Dr. Lagarias will investigate several independent topics interacting among these fields. The first, and main, topic continues the investigation of the Lerch zeta function, which is a function of three variables, that on specializing variables yields the Hurwitz zeta function and Riemann zeta function. A connection is made with the representation theory of the Heisenberg group and related groups, and the project aims to connect it more closely to automorphic representations on various groups. A second topic concerns two exploratory projects; one concerns a certain family of virtual representations of the symmetric groups, which arises as a degenerate limit of splitting properties of polynomials (modulo p), associated to properties of the discriminant locus of the polynomial. It asks if there is an underlying geometric structure explaining the observed limit properties, possibly with an associated dynamical system. Another exploratory project studies polyharmonic modular forms, which are functions with modular invariance that are annihilated by a power of the Laplacian. A third topic is to investigate of circle packings on Riemann surfaces, a topic in the area of discrete geometry. It considers formulation of scaling limits of such packings in two directions, a complex variables limit and a Diophantine approximation limit. Whether or not this can be done precisely, special questions are proposed to initially investigate these areas, including study of surfaces having rigid packings with a finite number of circles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research on this grant explored connections between number theory, which concerns discrete objects --the integers,  and other subjects, including topology, the study of shape, and harmonic analysis, the study of functions as superpositions of waves, both of which treat continuous objects.  A discrete object viewed from far  away can look continuous, just as the letters of this sentence, built from small dots (pixels), look continuous. Quantities extracted from these continuous structures (invariants) can be taken back to potentially  shed light on properties of the discrete situation. Some kinds of continuous invariants can be analyzed harmonically to give yet another useful view of the same structure.  One can proceed in the reverse direction, to discretize a continuous structure, as is done in quantizing speech signals for phone calls, and then to reconstruct  a voice or image on the other side. One would like the reconstruction to be faithful to the original.

The topics of research included study of the Lerch zeta function, which is a fundamental number theory invariant that encodes information on both time and frequency shifts of integers. A connection was made relating its internal structure  to the Heisenberg group appearing in quantum mechanics. A second topic, the Farey fractions, play a fundamental role as atoms of discretization, and relate to deep problems in number theory. They are built from ratios, but the research carried out studied their  products, experimentally, and found the products to have interesting hidden patterns. Another paper studied quantization of the line on two different scales (dilated floor functions), and determined which scales give compatible  quantizations (that is, the quantizations agree when applied successively in either order). Circle packings on the surface of spheres allowed to move on that surface (constrained configuration spaces)  can be studied topologically, and their structure as a function of circle size exhibit topological changes possibly giving insight into phase transitions in materials science. One paper by a graduate student applied number theory to analyze three-wave resonances in Rossby waves in meteorology; such waves in the atmosphere can break down the ``polar vortex". 

Supported in part by this grant, fifteen papers were published, and two PhD theses were written. The results of this grant are published in peer reviewed journals. Nearly all articles, plus additional preprints, are available on the mathematics arXiv, a publicly available source. Dr. Lagarias gave lectures on these topics in seminars, colloquia and invited talks in the United States and abroad.

Broader Impacts. This research made connections of  problems in number theory to problems in other areas of mathematics including dynamical systems, topology and special functions. Two PhD students completed  a PhD during the period of this grant, one on  extensions of the Lerch zeta function to number fields and function fields, one on a concept of  indefinite zeta functions. Two papers above arose from  research with an undergraduate student coauthor as part of an NSF-supported REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates.) Dr. Lagarias supervised three additional PhD students during the grant period, and also mentored two postdoctoral researchers. Outside of the proposer's  institution, the University of Michigan, Dr. Lagarias gave  talks at other institutions in the United States and abroad, including public lectures  on mathematics in studying materials and the connection of mathematics with industry.
